li.p: If we have a function given by a formula, is there a way to write down the antiderivative?
How can we find the area between two curves?

introduction.p: We have been focused on finding the derivative of a function, we will now examin how to find the function who derivative is the function we are given. Our goal is given a function f(x) can we find a function F(x) such that \displaystyle \frac{dF}{dx}=f(x)?

assemblage.title: Antiderivative
assemblage.p: The antiderivative of a function f(x) is any function F(x) such that \frac{dF}{dx}=f(x). That is, f(x) is the derivative of F(x).

statement.p: Consider the function f(x)=2x, can we think of a possible antiderivative?

A possible antiderivative of this is F(x)=x^2 since F'(x)=2x=f(x). The antiderivative is not unique, another possible antiderivative could be F(x)=x^2+4 since again F'(x)=2x=f(x). Note that any constant can be added to x^2 since the derivative of a constant is 0! Thus the most gerneral antiderative is F(x)=x^2+C for a general constant C.

assemblage.title: Integral
assemblage.p: If F(x) is any antiderivative of a function f(x), then the indefinite integral of a function f(x) is \int f(x)dx=F(x)+C, where C is called the constant of integration.

introduction.p: The general problem of finding an antiderivative is difficult. In part, this is due to the fact that we are trying to undo the process of differentiating, and the undoing is much more difficult than the doing. For example, while it is evident that an antiderivative of f(x) = 2x is F(x) = x^2 and that an antiderivative of g(x) = 3x^2 is G(x) = x^3, combinations of f and g can be far more complicated. . This warrants the question, how do we find an antiderivative from a function given by a formula in general? We will begin to answer that question in this chapter.

subsection.title: Basic antiderivatives
subsection.p: What is involved in trying to find an antiderivative for each? From our experience with derivative rules, we know that derivatives of sums and constant multiples of basic functions are simple to execute, but derivatives involving products, quotients, and composites of familiar functions are more complicated. Therefore, it stands to reason that antidifferentiating products, quotients, and composites of basic functions may be even more challenging. We defer our study of all but the most elementary antiderivatives to later in the text.

assemblage.title: Constant Rule
assemblage.p:
For any constant k:
\int k dx=kx+C

statement.p: When evaluating the integral, the variable of integration is indicated by the dx, or dy, or dt at the end of the integral. \int 4dt=4t+C \int \pi dy=\pi y+C \int \frac{1}{4}dz=\frac{1}{4}z+C

\int x^2dx=\frac{x^3}{3}+C \int y^{3.4} dy=\frac{y^{4.4}}{4.4}+C If not in the form x^n you may have to rewrite as we did when taking the derivative \int \frac{1}{z^2}dz=\int z^{-2}dz=\frac{z^{-1}}{-1}+C=\frac{-1}{z}+C \int \sqrt{x}dx=\int x^{1/2}dx=\frac{z^{3/2}}{3/2}+C=\frac{2}{3}z^{3/2}+C

assemblage.title: Natural Log and Exponential Rules
assemblage.p:
Natural Log Rule
\int \frac{1}{x} dx=\ln|x|+C
It is important to include the absolute values in the natural log since the domain of the natural log is x\gt0.

subsection.p:
Before proceeding any further it will be useful to state two properties. Properties of Antiderivatives: Sums and Constant Multiples
Let f and g be functions that have an antiderivative and c a constant then
\int\left(f(x) \pm g(x)\right) dx= \int f(x)dx \pm \int g(x)dx
In words, the antiderivative of a sum or difference is the sum or difference of the antiderivatives. Or put another way, you can integrate term by term. \int cf(x) dx = c\int f(x)dx In words, a multiplied constant stays.
We can now put all these properties together, along with the rules we have stated and evaluate some more difficult examples.

statement.p: We will start by showing every step \int (4x^2+5x+6)dx=\int 4x^2dx+\int 5xdx+\int 6dx=4\int x^2dx+5\int x dx+\int 6dx=4\frac{x^3}{3}+5\frac{x^2}{2}+6x+C In general we do not need to show the steps of splitting the integal into seperate integrals, rather we will simpliy evaluate term by term as we did when finding the derivative. Similarly we will not show the step of factoring out a constant, rather the multiplied constant will simply stay along. Although unlike taking the derivative we can not often simplify the constant in one step.

Evaluate each of the following integrals using the rules we have developed.
\int (5x^3+6x-3)dx
\int \left(4x^{2.3}+5\sqrt{x}+\frac{3}{x^2}\right)dx
\int \left(\frac{4}{x}+4e^{8x}+6\right)dx

li.p:
First rewrite the terms to apply the power rule \int \left(4x^{2.3}+5\sqrt{x}+\frac{3}{x^2}\right)dx=\int \left(4x^{2.3}+5x^{1/2}+3x^{-2}\right)dx Then apply the rules of integration
\int \left(4x^{2.3}+5x^{1/2}+3x^{-2}\right)dx=4\frac{x^{3.3}}{3.3}+5\frac{x^{3/2}}{3/2}-3x^{-1}+C

subsection.title: Applications of Integration
subsection.p: We will now examine how we can find a specific function f(x) given its derivative f'(x). Suppose you know f'(x)=x^2+4 and wish to find f(x), to find this we can integrate: f(x)=\int f'(x) dx=\int (x^2+4)dx=\frac{x^3}{3}+4x+C. The issue of course is the +C, we wish to find a single function f(x), however we have found many possible functions, one for each possible value of the C. In order to find the specific funciton we need more information, we need to know the value of the function at a point. If this is given, this is called an initial condition.

statement.p: Find the function f(x) given that f'(x)=x^2+4 and f(0)=3.

First we integrate
f(x)=\int f'(x)dx=\int (x^2+4) dx=\frac{x^3}{3}+4x+C,
then we use the initial condition: f(0)=3, to find the value of C:
f(0)=\frac{0^3}{3}+4(0)+C=3
to solve for C=3 and thus we have our solution
f(x)=\frac{x^3}{3}+4x+3

subsection.p: From this example note that the initial condition does not always have to be at x=0, further more note that to find the value of C we must solve an equation.

statement.p: If we start with the same function as our provious example, f'(x)=x^2+4 but now we have the initial condition that f(3)=3, then the first step of evaluating the integral would remain the same, the difference would be in finding the value of C.

First we integrate
f(x)=\int f'(x)dx=\int (x^2+4) dx=\frac{x^3}{3}+4x+C,
f(3)=\frac{3^3}{3}+4(3)+C=3
solving we get C=-21 and we now get:
f(x)=\frac{x^3}{3}+4x-21.
Find the function g(t) given that g'(x)=6e^{3t}+\frac{2}{t} and g(1)=5.

First we integrate
g(t)=\int g'(t)dt=\int (6e^{3t}+\frac{2}{t}) dt=\frac{6e^{3t}}{3}+2\ln|t|+C,
then we use the initial condition: g(1)=5, to find the value of C:
g(1)=2e^{3(1)}+2\ln|1|+C=5
to solve for C=5-2e^3 and thus we have our solution
g(t)=2e^{3(t)}+2\ln|t|+5-2e^3

subsection.p: Now lets examine some word problems in which we must find the function given the rate of change (derivative).

solution.p:
We are given the marginal cost, thus to find the cost function we must first integrate.
C(x)=\int\left(x^3-6x\right)dx=\frac{x^4}{4}+\frac{6x^2}{2}+C
Then to find the value of +C we will use the fact that the fixed costs are \$ 1200. Since this is fixed, this is the same as saying C(0)=1200, thus plug in x=0 to find the value of +C.
C(0)=\frac{0^4}{4}+\frac{6(0)^2}{2}+C=1200 \implies C=1200
Thus we find the total cost function
C(x)=\frac{x^4}{4}-3x+1200

statement.p:
A company finds that the rate at which the quantity of their item that comsumers demand changes with respect to the price and is given by the marginal demand function
D'(p)=-\frac{4000}{p^2},
where p is the price per item, in dollars. Find the demand function if 1015 items are demanded by consumers when the price is \$8 per item.

solution.p:
We are given the marginal demand function, thus to find the demand function we must first integrate.
D(p)=\int\left(\frac{-4000}{p^2}\right)dp=\int\left(-4000p^{-2}\right)dp=4000p^{-1}+C=\frac{4000}{p}+C
Then to find the value of +C we will use the fact that 1015 items are demanded by consumers when the price is p=8, thus D(8)=1015.
D(8)=\frac{4000}{8}+C=1015 \implies C=1015-500=515
Thus we find the demand function
D(p)=\frac{4000}{p}+515

statement.p:
The rate of change in Cheryl's pulse (in beats per minute per minute) t minutes after she stops exercising is given by
R'(t)=-46.964e^{-0.796t}.
Find R(t) if Cheryl's pulse is 78 beats per minute 2 minutes after she stopped exercising.

solution.p:
We are given the rate of change R'(t), thus to find R(t) we must first integrate.
R(t)=\int\left(-46.964e^{-0.796t}\right)dt=-46.964\frac{e^{-0.796t}}{-0.796}+C=59e^{-0.796t}+C
Then to find the value of +C we will use the fact that Cheryl's pulse is 78 beats per minute 2 minutes after she stopped exercising, that is R(2)=78.
R(2)=59e^{-0.796(2)}+C=78 \implies C=66
Thus we find that
R(t)=59e^{-0.796t}+66

exercise.title: Evaluating the definite integral of a rational function
Evaluating the definite integral of a linear function
Evaluating the definite integral of a quadratic function
Evaluating the definite integral of a trigonometric function

statement.p: The instantaneous velocity (in meters per minute) of a moving object is given by the function v as pictured in Figure. Assume that on the interval 0 \le t \le 4, v(t) is given by v(t) = -\frac{1}{4}t^3 + \frac{3}{2}t^2 + 1, and that on every other interval v is piecewise linear, as shown.

figure.caption: The velocity function of a moving body.

li.p: Determine the exact distance traveled by the object on the time interval 0 \le t \le 4.
What is the object's average velocity on [12,24]?
At what time is the object's acceleration greatest?
Suppose that the velocity of the object is increased by a constant value c for all values of t. What value of c will make the object's total distance traveled on [12,24] be 210 meters?
20 meters.

\displaystyle v_{\operatorname{AVG} [12,24]} = 12.5
meters per minute.
The object's maximum acceleration is 3 meters per minute per minute at the instant t = 2.

Since velocity is positive, distance traveled is the definite integral of velocity. Thus, on [0,4], the total distance, D, is
D = \int_0^4 v(t) \, dt = \int_0^4 \left( -\frac{1}{4}t^3 + \frac{3}{2}t^2 + 1 \right) \, dt . By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,
\int_0^4 \left( -\frac{1}{4}t^3 + \frac{3}{2}t^2 + 1 \right) \, dt &= \left. \left( -\frac{1}{16}t^4 + \frac{1}{2}t^3 + t \right) \right|_{t=0}^{t=4} &= -\frac{1}{16}4^4 + \frac{1}{2}4^3 + 4 &= 20 , so the distance traveled by the object on [0,4] is 20 meters.

To find the average velocity of the object on [12,24], we first evaluate \int_{12}^{24} v(t) \, dt. To do so, we use the fact that v is piecewise linear and employ standard geometric formulas to determine the value of the integral. The area of the trapezoid formed by v(t) and the vertical line segments at t = 12 and t = 16 is
A_1 = \frac{1}{2}(f(12) + f(16))(4) = 2(9 + 15) = 48 . The area of the rectangle formed by v(t) and the vertical line segments at t = 16 and t = 20 is
A_2 = 4 \cdot 15 = 60 . Finally, the area of the trapezoid formed by v(t) and the vertical line segments at t = 20 and t = 24 is
A_3 = \frac{1}{2}(f(20) + f(24))(4) = 2(15 + 6) = 42 . Thus,
\int_{12}^{24} v(t) \, dt = A_1 + A_2 + A_3 = 48 + 60 + 42 = 150 , from which it follows that
\displaystyle v_{\operatorname{AVG} [12,24]} = \frac{1}{24-12} \int_{12}^{24} v(t) \, dt = \frac{150}{12} = 12.5
meters per minute.

To find where a(t) is greatest, we recall that a(t) = v'(t), so we are seeking the location where the slope of the tangent line to v(t) is maximized on the interval [0,24]. From the graph, there are only two possible intervals where this can occur: 0 \lt t \lt 4 and 12 \lt t \lt 16, as these are both where v is increasing and thus a(t) = v'(t) is positive.

On 12 \lt t \lt 16, a(t) = v'(t) = \frac{3}{2} since this is the slope of the line that forms v(t) on this interval. On 0 \lt t \lt 4, v(t) = -\frac{1}{4}t^3 + \frac{3}{2}t^2 + 1, so a(t) = v'(t) = -\frac{3}{4}t^2 + 3t. We see that a(t) is a quadratic function that opens down, so its maximum occurs at its vertex, which is located where a'(t) = 0. We know that a'(t) = -\frac{3}{2}t + 3, and 0 = -\frac{3}{2}t + 3 implies t = 2. Moreover, a(2) = v'(2) = -\frac{3}{4} \cdot 2^2 + 3(2) = 3. Clearly a(2) = 3 \gt \frac{3}{2}, so the object's maximum acceleration is 3 meters per minute per minute at the instant t = 2.

Let V(t) = v(t) + c be the new velocity function that is the original velocity v increased by c at every time. We want to know the value of c for which total distance traveled is 210 meters. For this to be true, we must have that
210 = \int_{0}^{24} V(t) \, dt = \int_{0}^{24} \left( v(t) + c \right) \, dt . Using the additive property of the definite integral and our earlier work in (b), we can say that
210 = \int_{0}^{24} v(t) \, dt + \int_{0}^{24} c \, dt = 150 + \int_{0}^{24} c \, dt , so
\int_{0}^{24} c \, dt = 60 . Since the function f(t) = c is constant, the integral \int_{0}^{24} c \, dt represents the area of a rectangle 24 units wide and c units tall, so \int_{0}^{24} c \, dt = 24c. Hence,
24c = 60
so c = \frac{60}{24} = 2.5.

exercise.title: Evaluating the definite integral of a piecewise function

statement.p:
A function f is given piecewise by the formula
f(x) = \begin{cases} -x^2 + 2x + 1, \amp \ \text{if} \ 0 \le x \lt 2 \\ -x + 3, \amp \ \text{if} \ 2 \le x \lt 3 \\ x^2 - 8x + 15, \amp \ \text{if} \ 3 \le x \le 5 \end{cases} .
Determine the exact value of the net signed area enclosed by f and the x-axis on the interval [2,5].
Compute the exact average value of f on [0,5].
Find a formula for a function g on 5 \le x \le 7 so that if we extend the above definition of f so that f(x) = g(x) if 5 \le x \le 7, it follows that \int_0^7 f(x) \, dx = 0.

li.p: \displaystyle f_{\operatorname{AVG} [0,5]} = \frac{1}{2}.
g(x) = f(x) for 0 \le x \lt 5 and g(x) = -\frac{5}{4}(x - 5) on 5 \le x \le 7.

The net signed area enclosed by f and the x-axis on the interval [2,5] is \int_2^5 f(x) \, dx. The figure below shows a graph of f on the interval [0,5]. To calculate the definite integral of f on the interval [2,5], we consider the integrals on the subintervals [2,3] and [3,5]. Doing so and using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,
\int_2^5 f(x) \, dx &= \int_2^3 f(x) \, dx + \int_3^5 f(x) \, dx &= \int_2^3 -x+3 \, dx + \int_3^5 x^2-8x+15 \, dx &= \left. \left( -\frac{1}{2}x^2 + 3x \right)\right|_2^3 + \left. \left( \frac{1}{3}x^3 - 4x^2 + 15x \right)\right|_3^5 &= \left(\frac{9}{2}-4\right) + \left( \frac{50}{3}-18 \right) &= \frac{127}{6} - 22 = -\frac{5}{6} .

Since \int_0^5 f(x) \, dx = \frac{5}{2}, we need a function g that matches f but that is also defined on [5,7] so that \int_5^7 g(x) \, dx = -\frac{5}{2}. To preserve continuity, we will choose a formula for g that also satisfies g(5) = 0. It's natural to pick a linear function whose graph encloses 5/2 units of area, so one that has a slope of 5/4. To check, we compute
\int_5^7 -\frac{5}{4}(x - 5) \, dx &= -\left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \left. \left(\frac{x^2}{2} - 5x\right) \right|_5^7 &= -\left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \left( \frac{49-25}{2} - 5(7-5) \right) &= -\left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \left( 12 - 10 \right) &= -\left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \left( 2 \right) = -\frac{5}{2} . So g defined so that g(x) = f(x) for 0 \le x \lt 5 and g(x) = -\frac{5}{4}(x - 5) on 5 \le x \le 7 has the desired property. A graph of g is shown in the figure below.
